head.title: Lookin' Out For the Right Sound

hedline.hl1: Lookin' Out For the Right Sound

abstract.p: Ben Ratliff reviews performance by jazz saxophonist Antonio Hart and his band at Iridium; photo (M)

block.p: Antonio Hart had already worked through a number of different styles -- bebop with a free time feeling, powerhouse rhythm-and-blues, a bit of gospel -- but a song dedicated to the recently deceased pop-jazz icon Grover Washington Jr. gave him the opportunity to take his set in yet another direction.

What Mr. Hart and his band did in their early show on Wednesday at Iridium was to play the syntax of pop-jazz -- the popping electric bass, the reassuringly slow and articulated melodies, the light funk rhythms, the fussy percussion instruments -- but with much more interesting harmonic material inside it. His pianist, Kevin Hays, played wide chords slowly against the pulse, and he suspended time. It was a curious transformation of a type of music that normally doesn't go very deep.

His pianist, Kevin Hays, played wide chords slowly against the pulse, and he suspended time. It was a curious transformation of a type of music that normally doesn't go very deep.

Mr. Hart's path has been a typical one for a jazz musician in his mid-30's. Signed by a major label in the early 90's when it seemed that there might be a new youth market for jazz, he's now a free agent, and he's spent a few years traveling and taking a break from leading a band: going to Cuba, as so many younger jazz musicians are doing, studying rhythm and showing up as a guest in various bands from that of the jazz bassist Dave Holland to the hip-hop performer Common's.

As he played with his quintet, he was working hard. He's at least as interested in the old-style lyrical saxophone players of rhythm-and-blues, like King Curtis, as he is in the note-encrusted, fast-patterned style of Charlie Parker, and both styles came through in the set. Mr. Hart has got the modern musician's grip on harmony as well as a surging, earthy momentum and a broad sound. A few soprano-saxophone ballads from a forthcoming record on Enja indicated that he's examining how to write songs with simpler, more durable melodies, and he closed with a few burly blues choruses.

Clearly Mr. Hart is in a growth period, and as he extracts different combinations of elements from the recent history of black music, he's working toward a new revision of jazz that could -- when the dust settles -- appeal directly to his own generation.
